@drmommydoc1 20 years spent on drug development, evaluation of safety and confirmation of efficacy with an RCT is scientific discovery. 20 years spent on thumb twiddling until someone else's RCT makes you reverse your policy is scientific malpractice. The difference is not subtle.

Talk about non-Lindy: AAP’s recommendations have an automatic 5-year expiration date, unless explicitly renewed. They are treating clinical guidelines like a carton of milk. You have to be totally ignorant of human psychology to think this is sound policy. #RWRI [link]

@Willyintheworld @adamcifu Agree, in part. The threat of IRBs for clinical research is a bit exaggerated, other roadblocks are underappreciated. It’s possible we don’t have as many RCTs in children because regulatory overhead inflates costs (in both time and money), and there are fewer research $s in peds.

And in less than 2 decades, AAP went from No Peanuts Until Age 3! to promoting early introduction of peanuts to infants at high risk of developing allergy. Which makes you think about how they came up with their originial recommendation… [link] https://t.co/6FqkTXxedL
@rationalwalk Twitter has many good 3rd-party apps that remove promoted tweets and do not play around with the timeline. @tweetbot and @Twitterrific are the best.
